Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Story: I sat in my truck outside the client’s house, staring at the text from my mom. “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Call us when you can.” I hadn’t replied since Friday, and it was already Sunday afternoon. Guilt gnawed at me; I knew how much my parents valued our weekend check-ins, especially since Dad’s health scare last year. But inside the house, the homeowner was waiting anxiously. The termite damage was worse than I’d expected—beams sagging, floorboards soft underfoot. They needed a repair plan today, and I could hear the urgency in their voice when they called me this morning. My phone buzzed again. Another message from Mom: “Just want to hear your voice.” I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. My parents needed reassurance, but my client needed answers. I gripped my phone, heart pounding, caught between the son I wanted to be and the carpenter I was expected to be.
